awd_titl_txt: Constructing Race-Specific Driving Patterns to Address Racial Profiling
awd_abstract_narration:
While there is substantial evidence suggesting the presence of racial and ethnic bias in police treatment of people of color throughout the United States, there is little to no empirical evidence indicating that police profile people of color for police contact. Identifying whether and the extent to which the police are profiling people of color for traffic stops is notoriously difficult. This lack of empirical evidence undermines efforts to correctly diagnose and intervene in racially biased policing behavior. Further, in addition to the negative experience(s) that minority groups have with police, when people feel treated unjustly by the police, they lose their faith in law enforcement’s authority to fairly represent and administer the law. When this occurs, individuals are less likely to obey the law. Therefore, when the police target people of color for traffic stops, it feeds a cycle of distrust for both parties, potential criminality, and stereotypes that have plagued societal relations, policing and crime rates in the United States, for decades. In short, it is absolutely essential to accurately measure racial profiling by the police.

The purpose of this research is to synthesize and analyze a disparate suite of publicly available transportation data that includes the Census Transportation Planning Products (CTPP), accident data, as well as data from the National Household Travel Survey (NHTS) and its oversamples to develop a methodological framework for constructing race-specific driving patterns to address racial profiling of drivers by the police. The first objective of this project focuses on the design of innovative methods to integrate both geographic and transportation data with varying spatial and temporal resolutions for resolving the denominator problem and creating a generalizable framework for estimating racially motivated traffic stops. The second objective focuses on measuring and establishing the validity of the methods used to determine racial profiling by using open source policing data to evaluate the racial and ethnic distribution of individuals who would be stopped if the police were not racially biased while simultaneously accounting for police activity in a location. The third objective focuses on the design of an open-source distribution platform for the developed methods and redistributable data, and made available through well-documented Python and R front ends to facilitate the use, re-use and expansion of the methods and data used for this project. When combined, these measurements, methods, and statistical models will inform policymakers and law enforcement agencies about biased police practices and provide a blueprint for improving outcomes and reducing the cycle of distrust between the police and communities of color.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to accurately construct driving patterns, disaggregated by race or ethnicity, continues to elude researchers. This gap is significant because developing a deeper understanding of race-specific driving patterns is crucial for illuminating and solving some of the most pressing issues facing our society, including discrimination by the police, segregation, and employment disparities by race, to name a few. Typically, one calculates driving patterns through aggregate trip data from the Census Transportation Planning Package (CTPP); however, the CTPP is limited because it inhibits researchers from examining trip data across time, smaller spatial units, and driver characteristics. Further, in locations where race-specific driving patterns are available, the data focus on one city and emphasize employment-related travel, not the overall driving decisions and patterns we see daily. In criminology, this is known as the “denominator problem,” where racial profiling in policing cannot be determined because race-specific driving patterns have not yet been able to be calculated. The purpose of this research is to synthesize and analyze a disparate suite of publicly available spatial and transport data to solve the denominator problem and develop a methodological framework for constructing race-specific driving patterns to address the racial profiling of drivers by the police. Below, we detail the project outcomes and achievements.

Our most important outcome is the creation of race-specific driving patterns. One cannot overstate the importance of these driving patterns: our results represent the first complete treatment and methodological framework for establishing driving patterns (i.e., all of the decisions drivers make when traversing city streets for their daily lives) by different races (Wei et al., 2023; Yi et al., 2023; Zhao et al., 2024). Our team has taken these driving patterns and shown that where different races drive in a city is related to on-road segregation (Zhao et al., 2023). In addition, we have examined racial profiling, or in our project, the targeting of people of color for traffic stops. As a result, we addressed one of the core issues within racial profiling scholarship: are differences in traffic stops due to people of color being more “criminal on the road” or because the police incorrectly assume that people of color are more criminogenic than other races? Our findings show that all races are equally likely to be involved in problematic driving behavior (i.e., behavior that violates driving laws) that leads to accidents. This result is a step major forward in understanding racial profiling (Gutierrez et al., 2024). To date, this project has produced ten publications, multiple professional presentations, and while the grant is closed, work continues as we refine our methods and analyses further and apply this research to adjacent areas.

Finally, one of the most important products of this grant is the training of several PhD and undergraduate students. Situated at Arizona State University and the University of Utah, the PhD students on the project gained extensive training in transportation sciences/engineering, spatial analysis, geographic information science, natural language processing, working with administrative data, and project management techniques like project pipelining. Additionally, the undergraduates on the project gained experience using publicly available data to understand complex social problems, such as racism and policing. A handful of student presentations are listed below.

References:

Wei, R., Knaap, E. & Rey, S. American Community Survey (ACS) Data Uncertainty and the Analysis of Segregation Dynamics. Popul Res Policy Rev 42, 5 (2023). https://doi.org/10.1007/s11113-023-09754-6

Yi, Z., Chen, B., Liu, X. C., Wei, R., Chen, J., & Chen, Z. (2023). An agent-based modeling approach for public charging demand estimation and charging station location optimization at urban scale. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 101, 101949.

Zhou, Y., Wei, R., Liu, X. C., Wallace, D., & Grubesic, T. (2023). Delineating race-specific driving patterns for identifying racial segregation. Transportation Research Part D: Transport and Environment, 119, 103769.

Zhou, Y., Liu, X. C., Chen, B., Grubesic, T., Wei, R., & Wallace, D. (2024). A data-driven framework for agent-based modeling of vehicular travel using publicly available data. Computers, Environment and Urban Systems, 110, 102095.

Presentations:

Gutierrez, Suhey, Seanika Mathis, Abrielle Saunth, Seth Watts, Danielle Wallace. “Is Law-Violating Driving Behavior Race-Specific? Mapping Rates of At-Fault Traffic Accidents by Race.” Western Society of Criminology, Long Beach CA. February, 2024.

Connor Stewart and Danielle Wallace. “Untapped: A Machine-Learning Approach to Analyzing Text in Open-Ended Survey Responses and Beyond.” American Society of Justice Sciences. Chicago, IL. March, 2024
